content.description:
Include correctly labeled diagrams, if useful or required, in explaining your answers. A correctly labeled diagram must have all axes and curves clearly labeled and must show directional changes. If the question prompts you to “Calculate,” you must show how you arrived at your final answer.

The table provided shows macroeconomic data for the economy of Liang Island in 2020. The GDP deflator was 150 in 2020.

Macroeconomic Variables
 Value (in millions)

Personal Consumption Expenditures
 <math alttext="$70" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>70</mn></math>

Government Spending
 <math alttext="$25" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>25</mn></math>

Gross Private Domestic Investment
 <math alttext="$10" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>10</mn></math>

Personal Income
 <math alttext="$90" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>90</mn></math>

Exports
 <math alttext="$20" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>20</mn></math>

Imports
 <math alttext="$5" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>5</mn></math>

Population
 <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>

(a) Calculate the nominal gross domestic product (GDP) in 2020. Show your work.

(b) Based on your answer to part (a), calculate the real GDP in 2020. Show your work.

(c) Explain the conceptual difference between nominal GDP and real GDP.

(d) Assume real GDP in 2019 was $120 million and the population of Liang Island did not change from 2019 to 2020. Based on your answer to part (b), did the economy of Liang Island experience economic growth in per capita terms in 2020? Explain using numbers.

(e) What is one specific fiscal policy action the government of Liang Island can take to promote long-run economic growth? Explain.
content.question: Respond to all parts of the question.

frqParts.text: Respond to all parts of the question.

unit.text: 2: Economic Indicators and the Business Cycle

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Describe the similarities, differences, and limitations of economic concepts, principles, or models.
